item.title: Will of William Spencer, clothier 1699
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Spencer was still working as a clothier although the trade had generally declined in Basingstoke at this time. He left 12s. apiece to all his workers for them to buy gloves. He also left 20s. to be distributed in bread to the poor of Basingstoke. He owned a house in Basingstoke and another in Reading which he left to his two sons and daughter on condition that they paid their mother £6 per annum. Other bequests were made to his nephews, grandchildren and other family members.

 

Asset File: 
william_spencer_clothier_w_hro_1699a-71.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will and Inventory of Robert Lancaster, glover 1699
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Lancaster was a glover, possibly never married and elderly as he left bequests of £25 to each of three cousins and his sister and the remainder of his assets to two brothers. Although his monetary bequests amounted to £100 his inventory only totalled £24 1s. He had a kitchen well stocked with implements and a looking glass, a sign of status. His inventory did not reflect his trade other than to call one room his ‘working chamber’.

 

 

Asset File: 
robert_lancaster_glover_wi_hro_1699a-54.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will of Joseph Mooreing, gentleman 1698
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Mooreing was a gentleman with property in Basingstoke, Basing, Rotherwick, Hook and fields in Andover which he left to his nephews. He initially left his malt house in Basingstoke to nephew Christopher, but in a codicil he stated that he didn’t know if Christopher was dead or alive as he was in the ‘Island of Virginia’ so re-distributed the properties between the other nephews. Also, he initially left his maid servant £50 but as she had married and left his service he reduced this to £5. No inventory survives.

 

Asset File: 
joseph_mooreing_gent_w_1698_prob_11-443-55.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will of Michaell Acton, clerk 1697
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Acton was a clerk and probably the brother of Edward, gentleman (d. 1686). He left valuable bequests of rings, silver and gold items to family members, his old nurse, servants and friends. He also willed the patronage of Collingbourne Ducis in Wiltshire to his brother Edward. He pledged five guineas to New College, Oxford to buy divinity books and specified a book entitled Sandy’s Travels to be given to a friend.

 

Asset File: 
michael_acton_clerk_w_1697_tna_prob_11-439-26.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will of John Rogers, clerk 1696
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Rogers was a clerk and widower who asked to be buried beside his wife in the chancel of the parish church. He left his properties and monetary bequests to his six children and two grandchildren. He divided his books and manuscripts between two sons and specifically £6 per annum to his son Nicholas ‘in case he meet with no better preferment than that he now has’. He also instructed bread to be made for the poor of Basingstoke and Eastrop.

 

Asset File: 
john_rogers_clerk_w_hro_1696b-52.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will and Inventory of Thomas Edwards, tanner 1696
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Edwards was a widower who left the majority of his possessions to son Henry and just 1s. each to a second son and his daughter. His inventory listed hides and bark for his tanning business to the value of £62. 

 

Asset File: 
thomas_edwards_tanner_wi_hro_1696a-036.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will and Inventory of Edmund Cowdry, collarmaker 1695
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Cowdry was a collarmaker who made saddles and harnesses for horses. He left two houses in Basingstoke to his wife and then to two of his sons. Another son was his apprentice. He left bequests to a fourth son and two married daughters one of whom was expecting her first child. His inventory listed £40 of hides and finished items.

 

Asset File: 
edmund_cowdry_collar_maker_wi_hro_1696a-031.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Renunciation and Inventory of Joseph Windover, collarmaker 1694
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Windover died intestate and his father renounced his duty to administer the goods, passing responsibility to Joseph’s brother. Windever was a collar maker, i.e. he made harnesses and collars for horses. His inventory included details of tools, hides, and finished articles ready for sale. He also owned a shop in Odiham. His total inventory amounted to £402 10s. 2d., but £285 12s. of this was due in debts, bonds and securities.

 

Asset File: 
joseph_windover_collarmaker_wi_hro_1694ad-221.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will of John Box, innholder 1694
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Box described himself as an innkeeper but there is no hint of this in his will and no inventory survives. He left £25 to one son and £100 to each of five other children. He was probably a young man as he left provision for bequests to any future children that may be born to him and his wife after the signing of his will. He owned property in Basingstoke and Sherborne St John.

 

 

Asset File: 
john_box_innkeeper_w_hro_1694a-015.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Will of John Bourne/Borne, scrivener 1694
item.description:
Copyright: 
Hampshire Wills Group

Bourne/Borne was a scrivener born in Kingsclere. He left the poor of that parish and those in Basingstoke 10s. He owned cottages, 8 acres of land and an inn called the King’s Head in Basingstoke which he left to his cousin living in the parish of Weston Corbett. No inventory survives.

 

Asset File: 
john_borne_scrivener_w_1694_hro_1694a-014.docx_22.pdf
